1. Introduction

In earlier work [Ka-RLSFM], Katz exhibited some very simple one parameter families of exponential sums which gave rigid local systems on the affine line in characteristic pğ‘p whose geometric (and usually, arithmetic) monodromy groups were SL2â€‹(q)subscriptSL2ğ‘\mathrm{SL}_{2}(q), and he exhibited other such very simple families giving SU3â€‹(q)subscriptSU3ğ‘\mathrm{SU}_{3}(q). [Here qğ‘q is a power of the characteristic pğ‘p, and pğ‘p is odd.] In this paper, we exhibit equally simple families whose geometric monodromy groups are the alternating groups Altâ€‹(2â€‹q)Alt2ğ‘\mathrm{Alt}(2q). We also determine their arithmetic monodromy groups. See Theorem 3.1. [Of course from the resolution [Ray] of the Abhyankar Conjecture, any finite simple group whose order is divisible by pğ‘p will occur as the geometric monodromy group of some local system on ğ”¸1/ğ”½Â¯psuperscriptğ”¸1subscriptÂ¯ğ”½ğ‘{\mathbb{A}}^{1}/\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_{p}; the interest here is that it occurs in our particularly simple local systems.]

In the earlier work of Katz, he used a theorem to Kubert to know that the monodromy groups in question were finite, then work of Gross [Gross] to determine which finite groups they were. Here we do not have, at present, any direct way of showing this finiteness. Rather, the situation is more complicated and more interesting. Using some basic information about these local systems (cf. Theorem 6.1), the first and third authors prove a fundamental dichotomy: the geometric monodromy group is either Altâ€‹(2â€‹q)Alt2ğ‘\mathrm{Alt}(2q) or it is the special orthogonal group SOâ€‹(2â€‹qâˆ’1)SO2ğ‘1\mathrm{SO}(2q-1). The second author uses an elementary polynomial identity to compute the third moment as being 111 (cf. Theorem 7.1), which rules out the SOâ€‹(2â€‹qâˆ’1)SO2ğ‘1\mathrm{SO}(2q-1) case. This roundabout method establishes the theorem. It would be interesting to find a â€œdirectâ€ proof that these local systems have integer (rather than rational) traces; this integrality is in fact equivalent to their monodromy groups being finite, cf. [Ka-ESDE, 8.14.6]. But even if one had such a direct proof, it would still require serious group theory to show that their geometric monodromy groups are the alternating groups.

Remark 3.2.

The traces of elements of Altâ€‹(n)Altğ‘›\mathrm{Alt}(n) (respectively of Symâ€‹(n)Symğ‘›\mathrm{Sym}(n)) in its deleted permutation representation (respectively in every irreducible representation) are integers. Corollary 9.3.

We next show that GğºG is finite. It is convenient to use one more fact about GğºG. Theorem 9.4.

GğºG is finite.

Proof.

Suppose not. Let Nğ‘N be any nontrivial normal (closed) subgroup of GğºG. By Corollary 9.3, Nğ‘N is irreducible on Vğ‘‰V.

(i) Let G0superscriptğº0G^{0} be the identity component of GğºG. We now show that G0superscriptğº0G^{0} is a simple algebraic group. Taking N=G0ğ‘superscriptğº0N=G^{0}, we have that G0superscriptğº0G^{0} acts irreducibly and hence is semisimple (as it lies in SOâ€‹(V)SOğ‘‰\mathrm{SO}(V)). Moreover, the center of G0superscriptğº0G^{0} is trivial (because it consists of scalars in SOâ€‹(V)SOğ‘‰\mathrm{SO}(V)). Therefore if G0superscriptğº0G^{0} is not simple, it is the product of adjoint groups Ljsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—L_{j}, 1â‰¤jâ‰¤t1ğ‘—ğ‘¡1\leq j\leq t (namely the adjoint forms of the factors of its universal cover), and Vğ‘‰V is the (outer) tensor product V=âŠ—j=1tVjV=\otimes^{t}_{j=1}V_{j} of nontrivial irreducible Ljsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—L_{j}-modules Vjsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘—V_{j}. By [GT, Corollary 2.7], GğºG permutes these tensor factors Vjsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘—V_{j}. This action is transitive, otherwise we contradict Lemma 9.1. But this implies that Vğ‘‰V is tensor induced for GğºG, contradicting Lemma 9.2. Thus G0superscriptğº0G^{0} is a simple algebraic group.

(ii) Because the subgroup of GğºG generated by its pğ‘p-elements is Zariski dense, the finite group G/G0ğºsuperscriptğº0G/G^{0} is generated by its pğ‘p-elements. Suppose first that Ağ´A is connected and so a simple algebraic group. Then it contains a semisimple element xğ‘¥x acting with distinct eigenvalues.
